categories.name: Technical Accuracy
categories.description: Evaluates whether the curriculum correctly explains Bitcoin's protocol mechanics, cryptographic foundations, network architecture, consensus mechanism, and transaction lifecycle.

questions.text: Does the curriculum correctly explain the Bitcoin consensus mechanism (proof-of-work, longest chain rule, difficulty adjustment)?
questions.guidance: Look for accurate description of how miners compete to find valid blocks, why energy expenditure matters, and how difficulty adjusts every 2016 blocks.

questions.text: Does the curriculum accurately describe Bitcoin's cryptographic foundations (SHA-256, ECDSA/Schnorr signatures, hash functions)?
questions.guidance: Technical accuracy is essential. Check that the curriculum doesn't conflate encryption with hashing or make claims about 'unbreakable' security.

questions.text: Does the curriculum correctly explain how Bitcoin transactions work (inputs, outputs, UTXOs, scripts)?
questions.guidance: Look for accurate explanation of the UTXO model vs account model, transaction structure, and how change outputs work.

questions.text: Does the curriculum accurately describe the Bitcoin network architecture (nodes, miners, mempool, block propagation)?
questions.guidance: Check for distinction between full nodes, mining nodes, and SPV clients. Verify accurate description of how transactions propagate.

questions.text: Does the curriculum explain the 21 million supply cap correctly, including the halving schedule and subsidy mechanics?
questions.guidance: Verify accuracy of the halving schedule, block reward history, and the asymptotic approach to 21 million.

questions.text: Does the curriculum explicitly address and correct common technical misconceptions?
questions.guidance: Examples: 'Bitcoin is anonymous' (it's pseudonymous), 'transactions are instant' (requires confirmations), 'Bitcoin can be copied' (network effects).

questions.text: Are technical claims supported by references to primary sources (whitepaper, BIPs, Bitcoin Core documentation)?
questions.guidance: Quality curricula cite sources. Check for references to Satoshi's whitepaper, relevant BIPs, or developer documentation.

questions.text: Does the curriculum accurately explain key/address generation and the relationship between private keys, public keys, and addresses?
questions.guidance: Check for correct explanation of the derivation chain: private key → public key → address, and the role of hashing.

categories.name: Economic & Monetary Foundations
categories.description: Evaluates whether the curriculum situates Bitcoin within broader monetary history and economic theory.

questions.text: Does the curriculum explain Bitcoin's monetary properties (scarcity, divisibility, portability, durability, fungibility)?
questions.guidance: These are the classic properties of money. Check that each is addressed and compared to traditional forms of money.

questions.text: Does the curriculum provide historical context for monetary systems (gold standard, Bretton Woods, fiat)?
questions.guidance: Bitcoin is best understood in historical context. Look for explanation of how we got to the current monetary system.

questions.text: Does the curriculum explain inflation, deflation, and how Bitcoin's fixed supply relates to these concepts?
questions.guidance: Check for accurate explanation of how monetary inflation differs from price inflation, and Bitcoin's disinflationary schedule.

questions.text: Does the curriculum present multiple economic perspectives fairly (Austrian, Keynesian, MMT)?
questions.guidance: Quality education doesn't require students to adopt a particular economic school. Check for balanced presentation.

questions.text: Does the curriculum explain the role of central banks and how Bitcoin differs from centrally-managed money?
questions.guidance: Look for explanation of monetary policy, quantitative easing, and why decentralization matters.

questions.text: Does the curriculum address Bitcoin's volatility honestly, including its causes and implications?
questions.guidance: Volatility is a legitimate concern. Check that it's addressed rather than dismissed or ignored.

categories.name: Completeness of Coverage
categories.description: Evaluates whether the curriculum covers all essential Bitcoin topics without significant gaps.

questions.text: Does the curriculum cover Bitcoin's history and origin (cypherpunks, whitepaper, Satoshi, early development)?
questions.guidance: Understanding where Bitcoin came from provides essential context for why it was designed the way it was.

questions.text: Does the curriculum cover Bitcoin security practices (key management, wallet types, backup procedures)?
questions.guidance: Security is essential. Check for coverage of hot/cold wallets, seed phrases, and common security mistakes.

questions.text: Does the curriculum cover Bitcoin's scaling approaches (on-chain, Lightning Network, other Layer 2)?
questions.guidance: Scaling is a critical topic. Check for balanced coverage of different approaches and their tradeoffs.

questions.text: Does the curriculum cover regulatory and legal considerations relevant to the target audience?
questions.guidance: Learners need to understand the legal landscape. Check for coverage appropriate to the jurisdiction.

questions.text: Does the curriculum cover privacy considerations and Bitcoin's pseudonymous nature?
questions.guidance: Privacy is increasingly important. Check for coverage of chain analysis, privacy techniques, and tradeoffs.

questions.text: Does the curriculum address common risks (exchange failures, scams, user error, regulatory risk)?
questions.guidance: Honest education includes risks. Check that learners are warned about realistic dangers.

questions.text: Does the curriculum include practical exercises or hands-on components?
questions.guidance: Learning by doing is essential. Check for labs, exercises, or practical demonstrations.

categories.name: Pedagogical Quality
categories.description: Evaluates the teaching methodology and instructional design quality.

questions.text: Does the curriculum have clearly stated learning objectives for each module/section?
questions.guidance: Good instructional design starts with clear objectives. Check that learners know what they'll be able to do after each section.

questions.text: Is content sequenced logically, building from foundational concepts to advanced topics?
questions.guidance: Check that prerequisites are taught before dependent concepts. Look for a clear learning progression.

questions.text: Does the curriculum use appropriate analogies and examples to explain complex concepts?
questions.guidance: Good teaching makes abstract concepts concrete. Check for relatable examples and accurate analogies.

questions.text: Does the curriculum include assessments or knowledge checks?
questions.guidance: Assessment helps learners gauge their understanding. Check for quizzes, exercises, or other evaluation methods.

questions.text: Is the curriculum appropriate for its stated audience and skill level?
questions.guidance: Introductory content shouldn't assume expert knowledge. Advanced content shouldn't oversimplify.

questions.text: Does the curriculum provide additional resources for deeper learning?
questions.guidance: Quality curricula point learners to primary sources, further reading, and community resources.

questions.text: Are instructors/content creators qualified and their credentials clearly stated?
questions.guidance: Learners deserve to know who is teaching them. Check for clear instructor information.

categories.name: Neutrality & Objectivity
categories.description: Evaluates whether the curriculum maintains educational neutrality vs. becoming advocacy.

questions.text: Does the curriculum present Bitcoin's limitations and risks alongside its benefits?
questions.guidance: Education isn't advocacy. Check that drawbacks are honestly addressed, not hidden or dismissed.

questions.text: Does the curriculum avoid making price predictions or investment advice?
questions.guidance: Education should teach understanding, not promote speculation. Check for inappropriate financial advice.

questions.text: Does the curriculum fairly represent alternative viewpoints and critiques of Bitcoin?
questions.guidance: Learners should understand the strongest arguments against Bitcoin, not just strawman versions.

questions.text: Is the curriculum free from undisclosed commercial interests or conflicts of interest?
questions.guidance: Check for hidden promotion of specific products, services, or tokens. Sponsorships should be disclosed.

questions.text: Does the curriculum avoid tribal language or maximalist rhetoric that could alienate learners?
questions.guidance: Education should be welcoming. Check for dismissive language about other perspectives or technologies.

categories.name: Currency & Relevance
categories.description: Evaluates whether the curriculum is up-to-date and maintained.

questions.text: Has the curriculum been updated within the last 12 months?
questions.guidance: Bitcoin evolves. Content older than 12 months may contain outdated information.

questions.text: Does the curriculum reflect current protocol features (Taproot, Schnorr signatures)?
questions.guidance: Major protocol upgrades should be covered. Check for post-2021 developments.

questions.text: Does the curriculum address current regulatory landscape accurately?
questions.guidance: Regulatory information changes rapidly. Check that guidance reflects current reality.

questions.text: Is there a documented process for ongoing content review and updates?
questions.guidance: Sustainable quality requires maintenance. Check for update schedules or review processes.

questions.text: Does the curriculum reference current market conditions, adoption metrics, and ecosystem developments?
questions.guidance: Context matters. Check that examples and data are reasonably current.

categories.name: Accessibility & Inclusion
categories.description: Evaluates whether the curriculum is accessible to diverse learners.

questions.text: Is the curriculum available in multiple formats (text, video, audio)?
questions.guidance: Different learners have different needs. Check for format variety.

questions.text: Does the curriculum meet basic accessibility standards (screen reader compatible, captions, etc.)?
questions.guidance: Check for WCAG compliance, video captions, alt text, and keyboard navigation.

questions.text: Is the curriculum available in multiple languages or designed for translation?
questions.guidance: Bitcoin is global. Check for language accessibility beyond English.

questions.text: Are technical prerequisites clearly stated so learners can self-assess readiness?
questions.guidance: Learners shouldn't discover they're unprepared mid-course. Check for clear prerequisites.

questions.text: Is the curriculum priced accessibly or are scholarships/free tiers available?
questions.guidance: Cost can be a barrier. Check for accessibility options for resource-constrained learners.

categories.name: Ethical Standards
categories.description: Evaluates whether the curriculum upholds ethical obligations in education.

questions.text: Does the curriculum emphasize the importance of securing private keys and never sharing them?
questions.guidance: This is a fundamental security principle. Check that it's prominently emphasized.

questions.text: Does the curriculum warn against common scams and social engineering attacks?
questions.guidance: Learners are vulnerable to scams. Check for warnings about phishing, fake support, Ponzi schemes.

questions.text: Does the curriculum respect learner privacy and avoid unnecessary data collection?
questions.guidance: Privacy should be practiced, not just taught. Check the provider's data practices.

questions.text: Does the curriculum avoid promoting specific commercial products without disclosure?
questions.guidance: Undisclosed affiliate relationships or product placements undermine trust.

questions.text: Does the curriculum encourage responsible and legal use of Bitcoin?
questions.guidance: Education should not facilitate illegal activity. Check for appropriate guidance.
